summary: A memorandum from a retired warden to the Department of Justice Inspector General responding to a draft OIG report on Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. The warden defends the decision not to assign a backup cellmate to Epstein in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, citing institutional constraints, inmate movement, and safety concerns.

persons.name: Michael E. Horowitz
persons.context: Recipient of the memorandum; the official overseeing the Office of Inspector General investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate who died by suicide while housed in the Special Housing Unit at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide

events.title: Review of OIG Draft Report
events.description: The retired warden reviewed the Office of Inspector General's draft report concerning the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's suicide.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, New York
keyFacts: The retired warden states that prior to placing Epstein in the SHU, they vetted several inmates and identified only one as an appropriate cellmate.

The warden claims that due to the constant movement of inmates out of the SHU (via transfers, releases, or moves to other units) and the number of inmates posing a threat to Epstein's safety, there were no potential backup inmates available to house with him.
The document clarifies that pre-trial inmates (like Epstein) and designated inmates cannot be housed together, which limited the pool of potential cellmates.
The warden's core argument is that the decision not to select a backup cellmate was based on institutional mission, inmate movement, and safety assessments, not poor judgment.
